Recommended By Curators
"A stress management game with a very frightening and unsettling atmosphere that can easily make anyone feel tense. Why do the doors drain power!?!?!"

About This Game

Welcome to your new summer job at Freddy Fazbear's Pizza, where kids and parents alike come for entertainment and food as far as the eye can see! The main attraction is Freddy Fazbear, of course; and his two friends. They are animatronic robots, programmed to please the crowds! The robots' behavior has become somewhat unpredictable at night however, and it was much cheaper to hire you as a security guard than to find a repairman.

From your small office you must watch the security cameras carefully. You have a very limited amount of electricity that you're allowed to use per night (corporate budget cuts, you know). That means when you run out of power for the night- no more security doors and no more lights! If something isn't right- namely if Freddybear or his friends aren't in their proper places, you must find them on the monitors and protect yourself if needed!

Can you survive five nights at Freddy's?

"For all the simplicity of the game’s controls and premise, Five Nights at Freddy‘s is frightening. It’s a fantastic example of how cleverness in design and subtlety can be used to make an experience terrifying. Simple still images and proper character design steal the show in this game, and show that Scott Cawthon knows quite a lot about the secret fears people feel when looking at creepy dolls and toys. It’s elegant in how it sows fear, and is a must-own for anyone who likes scary games." -Joel Couture IndieGameMag.com

This game was created using Clickteam Fusion!
READ MORE

    • Processor: 2 GHz Intel Pentium 4 or AMD Athlon or equivalent
    • Memory: 1 GB RAM
    • Graphics: 1 GB
    • DirectX: Version 9.0
    • Hard Drive: 250 MB available space

[Snizza] EyesofWrath
422 products in account
103 reviews
Recommended
0.5 hrs on record
Posted: June 16
Genius in it's simplicity.

I finally bought this on sale just to see what the fuss was about, and after all the talk of the series being Youtube-bait with its jump-scares and the tiny development cycles of the sequels leading to them seemingly being churned out I was very cynical when starting it.

But I'll be damned if this isn't one of the most palpably tense horror games I've ever played.

Whilst the jump-scare aspect gets the most press when it comes FNAF, the game actually uses the core tenants of true horror to it's advantage. The player's influence on the world around him is limited - the only way you can fend off the creatures is to track the threat and close the doors around you when they appear. Given that operating anything uses up your precious power resources, you're left exposed for most of the game and can only act in your own defence when the threat is at your doorstep. Furthermore, you can only know that the threat is there if you turn on the lights temporarily, and the knowledge that there may be something watching you from the black abyss that lies just outside the door is terrifying in itself. So throughout the game the player is left powerless, exposed, fearing the unknown, feeling like the enemy is one step ahead, and incapable of eliminating the threat, only delaying it. These are the emotions that truly thrill you and scare you. The jump-scare is merely the pay off to the complex and deep tension that the game creates. And it does all this on a shoe-string, exposing just what a solid and simple concept can do for the gamer.

I now get why this game became so popular, and while the things you see and hear on Youtube may make you feel like the game is nothing more than a cheap thrill, I think it's a deceptively simple but masterfully crafted experience.
Read More
